The youth Candraprabha then addressed the Buddha, saying:

When one is about to die, how does consciousness abandon the body?
How does consciousness move the body?
How does consciousness know that it is now abandoning this body?
The Buddha told Candraprabha:

Sentient beings, according to their karma, receive retribution. Consciousness flows and continues, sustaining the body without interruption. When the allotted time is up and the retribution ends, consciousness abandons the body and migrates according to karma to receive [another body].
It is like mixing water and milk, heating them with the power of fire, and the milk, water, and fat each dispersing.
In this way, Candraprabha!

When the life of a sentient being ends, by the power of karma it disperses, and the body, consciousness, and various sense bases and elements each disperse separately. Consciousness serves as the basis, taking the dharma realm, thoughts of the dharma realm, and good and bad karma, and transmigrates to receive other retributions.
Candrasiddhi!

It is like the great auspicious ghee, which is a combination of the potency, potency, and efficacy of various good medicines, becoming the great auspicious ghee. Discarding the nature of ordinary ghee, holding the potency of good medicines, with the six flavors of bitter, pungent, sour, salty, astringent, and sweet, it nourishes the human body, and then gives the human body color, smell, and taste;
Consciousness discards this body, holds good and bad karma and the dharma realm, and transmigrates to receive other retributions, it is also like this.
Candrasiddhi!

Just as ghee is made by combining various medicines, all dharmas and faculties combine to form karma. The taste and touch of various medicines contribute to the formation of ghee, just as karma contributes to consciousness. Taking the great auspicious and wholesome [ghee] brings joy, nourishment, and fullness, with a radiant complexion, well-being, and freedom from illness, just as good karma contributes to consciousness and brings about the attainment of blissful rewards.

Taking ghee contrary to the Dharma changes one's appearance to be ugly, with a grim and lifeless complexion, and one dies with a pale face, just as evil karma contributes to consciousness and brings about the attainment of painful rewards.
Moon Reality!
The precious ghee of auspicious wholesomeness, without hands, feet, or eyes, is able to take good medicine, color, fragrance, taste, and potency;

Consciousness is also like this, taking the dharma realm, sensation, and various wholesome karma, abandoning this bodily realm and receiving the intermediate existence, attaining the wonderful thoughts of the heavens, seeing the six desire heavens and sixteen hells, seeing one's own body, with the extremities of the hands and feet dignified and the faculties beautiful, seeing the abandoned corpse, saying:
'This was my body in the previous life.

He also sees the high and excellent celestial palaces of the Mightily Illuminating Heaven, adorned in various ways, covered with flowers, fruits, trees, vines, and creepers, their radiance as brilliant as newly refined gold adorned with myriad jewels.

Having seen this, his mind is greatly delighted. Due to great joy and love, his consciousness then attaches to it. This person of good karma, when abandoning this body and receiving another body, is at ease and without suffering, like a rider who abandons one horse and mounts another.

It is just like a strong man fully equipped with martial skills, who, upon seeing the enemy troops approaching, dons solid armor, mounts his swift horse, and fearlessly goes forth. The consciousness, aided by the wholesome roots, abandons the in-and-out breath, abandons the realms and sense bases, and transfers to a body that experiences supreme bliss, in the same way. From the Brahma Heaven up to the Pinnacle of Existence, one is born within them.

World-Honored One!
What are the characteristics of consciousness?
Please explain it to me.
The Buddha told Great Medicine:

It is like a person's reflection appearing in water. This reflection cannot be grasped, and it cannot be distinguished as existent or non-existent. It is like the form of a straw dog, like the reflection of thirst.
Prince Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
What is thirst?
The Buddha said:
It is like when a person encounters a pleasing form, and the eye faculty pursues it, which is called thirst.
It is like holding up a bright mirror to see one's own facial image. If one moves away from the mirror, the facial image is not seen.
The transition of consciousness is also like this. The forms of good and evil karma and the images of consciousness are all invisible.
It is like a person born blind who does not know the sun rising, the sun setting, the day, the night, the light, or the dark.
Consciousness is unable to see in the same way.

Thirst, sensation, and perception in the body are invisible. The various great elements, sense bases, and aggregates of the body, they are all consciousness. The various physical forms such as eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body, as well as sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, and the formless mind that experiences suffering and pleasure, they are all also consciousness.

Just as the tongue can taste sweet, bitter, pungent, sour, salty, and astringent flavors, distinguishing all six tastes, the tongue and the food both have form and color, while the flavors are formless. The fruits of knowledge, merit, and demerit are also like this.
At that time, the youth Sudatta, the foremost of the wise, bowed at the Buddha's feet and said to the Buddha:

One who has not yet seen the truth cannot see consciousness. Consciousness cannot be seen, unlike an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of the hand. Consciousness is not within the eyes and so forth. If consciousness were within the eyes and so forth, one should be able to see consciousness by dissecting the eyes and so forth.

The Buddhas of the Ganges sands see consciousness as formless, and I also see consciousness as formless in the same way. Consciousness is not something that ordinary foolish people can see, but it is revealed through metaphors.
Virtuous Protector!
If you wish to know the sins and merits of consciousness, you should listen now!
It is like a person who is possessed by various celestial spirits, gandharvas, and so forth, as well as by the ghosts and spirits of the Sekadins.
Virtuous Protector!
What do you think?
Can the body of the one who is possessed by the celestial spirits and so forth be seen by searching within the body?
Virtuous Protector addressed the Buddha, saying:
No, World-Honored One!
The body of the one who is possessed by the celestial spirits and so forth has no form or shape, and it cannot be seen by searching inside or outside the body.
Virtuous Protector!

The merit that surpasses the great devas and celestial beings is to use good incense, flowers, and burn various famous incense, fragrant and delicious food, and arrange them in a pure manner. The offerings should all be fresh and clean. In this way, if this consciousness is supported by merit, one will obtain the fruits of noble status and happiness:

Either becoming a human king, or a prime minister, or having a prestigious and valuable status, or having wealth and freedom, or becoming a great elder, or becoming a great merchant leader, or obtaining a celestial body and experiencing the supreme celestial fruits.

Because the consciousness is supported by merit, the body obtains the reward of happiness, just like the devas and celestial beings who are supported by superior merit, obtaining superior and wonderful flowers, incense, fragrant and delicious food, and immediately becoming joyful and at ease. Now obtaining noble status, wealth, and freedom, one should know that this is all due to the consciousness being supported by merit, and the body obtaining the fruits of happiness.
Virtuous Protector!

Those possessed by the lower evil ghosts such as Putana will love filthy, rotten, and disgusting things, and by offering these to them they will be delighted and cured. The person, by the power of the ghosts, will love impure and foul things according to the ghosts' desires;

The consciousness, nourished by evil karma, is also like this. It may be born in poverty, or in hungry ghosts and various evil realms that eat filth, and due to the consciousness nourished by evil karma, the body will experience suffering.
Virtuous Protector!

The superior gods have no substance or form in their possessed bodies, yet they receive various fragrant and pure offerings. Consciousness, without form, experiences the superior blissful retribution in the same way;
The lower evil ghosts such as Putana, when possessed, will receive impure and foul food and drink. Consciousness, nourished by evil karma, experiences various suffering retributions in the same way.
Virtuous Protector!

One should know that consciousness has no form or substance, like the bodies possessed by gods and ghosts, and the good and bad obtained from offerings and food, like the suffering and happiness obtained from sin and merit.

World-Honored One!
How does one see the causes of desire?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

translated: Desire arises from mutual causes, just like the mutual causes of two sticks for making fire, adding human effort, and then fire is produced. In this way, desire arises from causes of consciousness, and causes of the colors, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects of men and women.
It is like the production of fruit from a flower. The fruit is not in the flower, but the fruit is born when the flower perishes.

In this way, consciousness manifests based on the body. Seeking consciousness by following the body, consciousness cannot be seen. The fruit of consciousness arises based on the body, and the body then perishes. The impure substances such as the body's bones and marrow all dissipate.
Moreover, it is like a seed holding the future fruit's flavor, color, smell, and texture, and being transplanted and born.
Consciousness abandons this body and takes the good and evil karma, perception, feeling, intention, and receives the retribution of the next life, also like this.

Moreover, it is like a man and woman who love each other and gather together, but separate and leave. Consciousness and karma come together, clinging and loving, enjoying and craving, but when the retribution is exhausted, they separate and follow karma to receive retribution. The parents' conditions and the intermediate existence face each other, and by the power of karma, consciousness produces the body's fruit. Love and karma are both formless, wanting to give rise to desire based on form and appearance, this is the cause of desire.
Great Medicine!
How does one see the cause of attachment to precepts?
Precepts refer to the precepts set by the teacher, such as not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not speaking falsely, not drinking alcohol, and so forth.

Grasping means clinging. This precept-keeping view is like this: Because of upholding this precept, one will attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning. For this cause, one will obtain a superior existence, namely, receiving a human or heavenly body. This is all contaminated good, not uncontaminated good.

Uncontaminated good has no conditioned fruition. Now, this grasping at precepts and views is planting with contamination. In the consciousness, one clings to good and evil karmic consciousness, not being pure and clean. Because of the cause of afflictions, one receives the suffering of heat and distress. This is called the cause of grasping at views and precepts.

One should see good and evil karma like the two phases of the moon in the sky, white and black, and also like a growing fruit, which changes color due to the increase of the fire element. In the same way, because of the increase of blessings, one is born in a family of high status, with abundant wealth and overflowing gold and treasures, with prominent and prosperous characteristics, or one is born in the palaces of the gods, with blissful freedom. All of these are the manifestations of the blessings of good karma.

It is like planting seeds in the ground, with the fruit appearing at the top of the tree. However, the seed does not enter from the branch to the top of the tree. Even if one cuts apart the body of the tree, one still does not see the seed. No one holds the seed and places it on the branch. When the tree is established with firm roots, one does not see the seed. In the same way, all good and evil karma depend on the body, but even if one seeks it in the body, one still does not see karma.

It is like how there is a flower because of the seed, but the flower is not in the seed. There is a fruit because of the flower, but the fruit is not in the flower. The flower and fruit progress, but the progress is not seen;
Because of the body there is karma, and because of karma there is a body. There is no karma in the body, and no body in karma, and it is the same.

Just as when a flower ripens and falls, its fruit becomes apparent. When the body matures and perishes, the karmic fruit emerges. Just as a seed has the causes of flowers and fruits, so does having a body contain the causes of good and evil karma. That karma has no form and no mature appearance.

Just as a person's shadow has no substance and no obstruction, it cannot be grasped or held, and does not bind or attach to the person. It moves forward and backward, following the person's movements, and one does not see the shadow coming out from the body;
The karmic body is also like this. There is a body and there is karma, but one does not see the karma, bound to the body, nor does it leave the body and yet be able to have karma.

Just as bitter, astringent, and pungent medicinal herbs can cleanse and remove all illnesses, causing the body to be full, nourished, and radiant, when people see this, they know that the person has taken good medicine. The taste of the medicine can be perceived, but the effect of the medicine has no form, it cannot be seen or grasped, yet it can nourish a person's complexion and radiance;
Karma, which has no form or substance, can nourish the body in the same way.

Those nourished by good karma will have abundant and beautiful food, clothing, and all kinds of resources, their hands and feet will be well-proportioned, their appearance will be lovely, their houses will be luxurious, and they will be filled with maá¹‡i jewels, gold, silver, and various treasures, enjoying peace, happiness, and pleasure to their heart's content. One should know that this is the characteristic of good karma.

Those born in low, poor, and remote places, lacking resources and longing for the happiness of others, with coarse and poor food or even no food, a wretched appearance, and living in a lowly place, one should know that this is the characteristic of bad karma.

It is like a bright mirror reflecting the good and bad of a face. The mirror image has no substance and cannot be grasped. In the same way, consciousness relies on good and bad karma to be born in the human or heavenly realms, or to be born in the hells, as an animal, and so forth.
Great Medicine!
You should see karma and consciousness as combining to bring about transformation in this way.
Great Medicine said:
World-Honored One!
How can such a subtle consciousness hold the faculties and grasp a large body?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

It is like a hunter entering the mountains and forests with a bow and poisoned arrows to shoot a fragrant elephant. The poison from the arrow contaminates the blood, and the poison spreads throughout the elephant's body, paralyzing its limbs and faculties, and the poison flows to the vital points, causing the elephant's body to turn blue and red like stagnant blood. After the elephant is killed by the poison, it immediately dies.
What do you think?
Can the amount and size of the poison be compared to the elephant's body?
Great Medicine said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The amount and size of poison and an elephant's body are vastly different and cannot be compared, just like Mount Sumeru compared to a mustard seed.
Great Medicine!
In this way, consciousness abandons this body and takes on the faculties, abandoning these elements and transforming according to karma, it is also like this.
Great Medicine again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How can such a subtle consciousness support a large body without becoming weary?
The Buddha said:
Great Medicine!

Mount Sumeru is 84,000 yojanas high, and the two great dragon kings Nanda and Upananda each encircle it three times. The two dragons' great breaths shake Mount Sumeru, and the water in the inner ocean all turns into poison.
These two dragon kings are long, powerful, and strong, equal to the two great dragon kings Vasuki and Takshaka.
What do you think?
Are the consciousnesses of the four dragon kings and the consciousnesses of mosquitoes and gadflies different?ğŸ”½Great Medicine!
MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya said:
World-Honored One!
The consciousness of the four dragons and mosquitoes is no different.
MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya!
Like a small drop of poison, if it enters the mouths of the four dragons, the four dragons will die.
What do you think?
Is the poison in the small drop or the poison in the dragon's mouth greater?
MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya said to the Buddha:
The poison in the dragon's mouth is greater, and the poison in the small drop is very small.
MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya!

The subtle consciousness of a large-bodied being, which is the equal of nine elephants in strength, has no form or shape, cannot be measured by discrimination, and is also like this in sustaining according to karma.
Like the seed of a fig tree, which is extremely tiny, when planted it grows into a tree with vast branches and leaves in the hundreds of thousands.
What do you think?
Is the size of the seed the same as the size of the tree?
MahÄ- bhaiá¹£ajya said:
World-Honored One!
The size of the seed and the size of the tree are as different as the hole of a lotus thread compared to the realm of space.
It is so, Great Medicine!
The tree cannot be found in the seed, but if there were no seed, the tree would not grow.

A tiny nyagrodha seed can produce a great tree, and a tiny consciousness can produce a large body. The body cannot be found in consciousness, and if consciousness is removed, the body would not exist.
Great Medicine again said to the Buddha:
How can the indestructible consciousness, which is as hard as diamond, abide within a fragile and quickly decaying body?
The Buddha said:

It is like a poor person who obtains a wish-fulfilling jewel. By the power of the jewel, a lofty and intricately carved palace appears, with lush gardens and groves, blooming flowers and luscious fruits, and female entertainers on elephants and horses. All the necessary articles for enjoyment naturally arrive;

Later, that person loses the wish-fulfilling jewel, and all the resources and pleasures disappear. The wish-fulfilling jewel is solid and true, and even a thousand vajras cannot destroy it. The resources it produces are false, impermanent, quickly scattered, and quickly extinguished.
Consciousness is also like this, solid and indestructible, but the body it produces quickly decays and is quickly extinguished.

World-Honored One!
How can the soft and wonderful consciousness penetrate into the coarse and hard form?
The Buddha said:

The essence of water is extremely soft, yet rushing streams and waterfalls can penetrate mountains and rocks.
What do you think?
How hard or soft are the qualities of water and stone?
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana said:
World-Honored One!
The quality of stone is hard, like vajra, while the quality of water is soft and pleasant to the touch.
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana!
Consciousness is also like this. It is extremely wonderful and soft, yet it can penetrate the coarse and large form, and transmigrate to experience the retribution.

How do sentient beings, when abandoning the body, take birth in the heavens?
And how do they take birth in the hells and other realms?

When sentient beings are about to die, those who are supported by meritorious karma abandon their original vision and attain the wondrous vision of the heavens,

using the wondrous vision of the heavens to see the six desire heavens and the six destinies, seeing their bodies shaking, seeing the heavenly palaces, the Joyful Garden, the Mixed Flower Garden, and so forth, and also seeing the gods dwelling in lotus flower palaces,
